message:
> Cancellation has different semantics than faulting: when you cancel a block, it will drop all of its currently-buffered items  

But faulting also drops all the items in the output queue. At least my test shows that faulting behaves the same as cancellation in this regard.  

Or did I misunderstand what you are saying?
Thank you so much, svick! My post was incorrect - fixed now.

Hi Stephen  
Can you tell how many blocks can be connected in a dataflow mesh?  
I am trying to construct a graph by Dataflow blocks, see the figure. The nodes with "op" are operational blocks, the ones with no text - input nodes. Each operational node is represented by custom block. The problem is that when I create a graph in the figure with 256 x 256 nodes, it consumes a lot of memory and I get OutOfMemoryException, although I still have RAM.   
Do you know any restrictions about the number of the blocks?

 [https://uploads.disquscdn.com/images/56f3ed1a961150a4ae7c09b4877a3d009e0ef67ddec886b92f71503d6ebc40eb.png](https://uploads.disquscdn.com/images/56f3ed1a961150a4ae7c09b4877a3d009e0ef67ddec886b92f71503d6ebc40eb.png)

I'm not aware of any specific restrictions, but I've never seen a dataflow mesh attempted like that, either.

If you're trying to model a neural network or something, there's far more efficient approaches than a dataflow mesh.

No, it is not about neural networks.  
With the Dataflow blocks I am trying to repesent cell depenedencies that occur in the spreadsheets. The pic above was the worst case I did.  
It turns out that they allocate a lot memory (as I get memory exception) and I would like to know if any resctrictions are present. Unfortunatelly, couldn't find any docs about the restrictions for the internal structures etc.

TPL Dataflow is a pretty heavy solution; its normal use case is to set up a mesh of a few nodes - say, 3-4 nodes - and then run a huge amount of data *through* it. I've only seen meshes get up to about a dozen in the most complex cases.

Your problem sounds like the opposite: you need tens of thousands of nodes, through which very little data will pass. I conclude that TPL Dataflow is probably not the right tool for your needs.
